awd_titl_txt: Advancing Technology, Access, Diversity, and Inclusion Through Curriculum Redesign of the Power Plant Technology Program
awd_abstract_narration:
In Oklahoma, the energy sector employs a large number of people and the number of jobs in this sector is expected to grow at least 15% by 2025.  This project intends to help fill the specific energy sector demand for skilled technicians in Power Plant Technology.  To do so, it will develop, implement, and field test new curriculum modules for the University’s existing Power Plant Technology program. This new curriculum will take advantage of a donated power plant simulator that is designed to teach operators about plant processes, monitoring, limitations, stabilization, and recovery after equipment malfunctions.  The new curriculum will include integration of learning modules into existing courses and creation of new courses for a hybrid format that includes in-person and online components.  These hybrid courses will provide the basis for future, entirely online curriculum. This updated curriculum will also be used as professional development for industry partners and to develop stackable certificates. In addition to making curriculum improvements, the project also intends to help improve diversity and inclusion within the energy sector and the Power Plant Technology program. To this end, the project will develop a strategic plan to teach future energy sector employees the core values that lead to a diverse and inclusive workforce.  In addition, it will help industry and educators recognize their own responsibilities in supporting a diverse, inclusive workplace.  It is expected that the diversity and inclusion strategic plan will provide a model for increasing student diversity and inclusion within the University, as well as for adaptation by regional workforce stakeholders.

The overarching goal of this project is to collaborate with industry and other stakeholders to educate an inclusive and diversified Power Plant Technology workforce.  This goal will be achieved by: 1) developing a new curriculum and re-designing course offerings; and 2) developing a strategic plan to create a more inclusive and diversified workforce. An external evaluator will interview faculty, industry stakeholders, and students to determine whether the new curriculum effectively addresses industry needs. Evaluation methods will focus on determining the effectiveness of course materials and instructional methods for different student populations. Formative evaluation will ensure that progress is being made on the curriculum development, course redesign, and strategic plan development. Summative evaluation will analyze and document how well the project succeeded in meetings its goals and objectives and how unanticipated challenges were handled. Project dissemination plans include presentations at STEM-related showcases, advisory board meetings, HI-TEC Conference, and at the ATE PI Conference and ATE Central. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OSU Institute of Technology’s Power Plant Technology project proposed a strategy for the development of high-quality, creative curriculum models which provides enhanced Power Plant Technology (PPT) curriculum. The primary focus of the curriculum modules was to incorporate advancing technologies within the energy sector, through re-imagined theory and "hands-on" simulator instruction. Second, the project sought to develop a strategic plan that addresses the need for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) within the energy sector and OSUIT’s Power Plant Technology program. The project was led by PI Robert Pope, instructor in the PPT program, and Co-PI Taler Adney, instructor in the business program.

The PI team worked steadily to problem solve and creatively fulfill project activities and deliverables. In Year 3, the team productively developed/refined and begun implementation of two key work products: 1) A comprehensive set of PPT learning materials and model curriculum (simulator lessons, lesson progression map); and 2) A revised Student Engagement Model that includes an Equitable Learning Environment aspect to the personalized one-on-one learning and career path approach the PPT program employs.

Additionally, this project sought to develop a strategic plan that addresses the need for DEI within the energy sector and OSUIT’s Power Plant Technology program. The strategic plan provides a roadmap that: 1) teaches future energy sector employees the core values that lead to a diverse, equitable, and inclusive workforce; 2) develops and communicates to industry and educators the responsibilities of industry and technical institutions; and 3) develops a best practice model in modern workforce development.

The overarching goal of this project was to build an inclusive, equitable, and diverse skilled technical workforce through a collaborative effort with industry/workforce partners and the enhancement of the current curriculum, equipment, and course offerings.

This goal was supported by two objectives: 1) Collaboration with industry partners to develop curriculum and re-design course offerings; and 2) Collaboration with industry partners and organizations, and other related entities to develop a strategic plan to create a more inclusive, equitable, and diverse workforce.

For objective #1, the PI team creatively and successfully 1) Redesigned and implemented the Power Plant Technology curriculum; and 2) Integrated simulator training and simulations into the curriculum as an experiential learning resource for students. Thirty-three lessons were identified for 11 of the courses in the degree. Nine lessons have been incorporated into student studies. Lesson incorporation follows cohort progress through the entire degree plan.

The integration of simulation into the PPT redesign was especially timely during the pandemic when plant access was severely curtailed, and education was making the shift to online/virtual/hybrid learning. Feedback from students indicates they like the flexibility of remote learning.

For Objective #2, the PI team worked closely with its institution to consider historical and demographic data specific to the PPT program. The general data pattern shows limited progress with underserved/underrepresented students in the program. One of OSUIT’s Strategic Plan goals is to “Enrich Services for Students.” Under the grant, the PI team developed and amended the program’s vision and mission statements and prioritized best practices that promote progress in this area.

The team specifically added the element of “access to an equitable learning environment.” The framework of an equitable learning environment is not that every student is provided the same resources; but rather, they are provided individualized resources that ensure access and engagement with the learning resources on an equal footing. In conjunction, the team also evolved and improved its high value individually tailored approach to the student experience from recruitment into the PPT program through career placement.

Over Summer 2023, PI Pope and the team developed a list of “Critical Success Factors” that relate directly to the successful completion of the Power Plant degree. This will be a baseline to check for each student’s equity to access the program. If gaps are identified for an individual student, the extended team of Power Plant Technology instructors, industry/community partners, and the School of Engineering & Construction Technology, will work together to address and fill gaps. This approach and concept came from OSUIT Diversity Training and from NSF ATE conference presentations and roundtables. Those experiences impressed on the PI team the importance of the institution-student relationship to successful learning for students.
